title: FC Aktobe
text:
Football Club Aktobe (), commonly referred to as FC Aktobe or simply Aktobe, is a professional <a href="association%20football">football</a> club based in <a href="Aktobe">Aktobe</a>. They last played in the <a href="Kazakhstan%20Premier%20League">Kazakhstan Premier League</a>, the highest level of <a href="Football%20in%20Kazakhstan">Kazakh football</a>. Formed as Aktyubinets in 1967, they became Aktobemunai in 1996, Aktobe in 1997, Aktobe-Lento in 2000 and finally Aktobe again in 2005. Their home ground is the 13,500 seat <a href="Central%20Stadium%20%28Aktobe%29">Central Stadium</a>.
Aktobe have won five <a href="Kazakhstan%20Premier%20League">league titles</a>, one <a href="Kazakhstan%20Cup">Kazakhstan Cup</a> and three <a href="Kazakhstan%20Super%20Cup">Kazakhstan Super Cup</a>. The club has also won two <a href="Soviet%20Second%20League">Soviet Second League</a> titles in 1981 and 1991.
History.
Aktobe was founded in 1967 as Aktyubinets. They played their first three seasons in the <a href="Soviet%20Second%20League%20B">Class B Division</a>, fourth tier of the <a href="Football%20in%20the%20Soviet%20Union">Soviet League system</a>. For the next 7 seasons, they were not active in official tournaments. In 1976, the club joined the <a href="Soviet%20Second%20League">Soviet Second League</a>, to play in its Zone 7, and in 1981, they won the championship . In 1990, the team recorded a 10–0 victory over <a href="FC%20Bolat">Bulat</a>, which remains the club's biggest victory on record. In the 1991 season, the last year of Soviet League existence, the club won Zone 8 Championship.
Following the <a href="dissolution%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a>, the club joined the newly formed <a href="Kazakhstan%20Premier%20League">Kazakhstan Premier League</a>. In 1994, Aktyubinets reached <a href="Kazakhstan%20Cup">Kazakhstan Cup</a> final, which they lost to <a href="FC%20Vostok">Vostok</a> with a score of 0–1. In 1996, the club changed name to Aktobemunai. However, after one season they renamed again to Aktobe. As the result of reduction of league teams in 1997, Aktobe was relegated to the <a href="Kazakhstan%20First%20Division">Kazakhstan First Division</a>. In the 2000 season, the club won Kazakhstan First Division and were promoted to the Kazakhstan Premier League.
On 20 July 2015, <a href="Ioan%20Andone">Ioan Andone</a> was appointed as the club's manager. After finishing Third in the league, on 10 November 2015, Andone left the club after his contract wasn't extended.
On 22 December 2015, <a href="Yuri%20Utkulbayev">Yuri Utkulbayev</a> was announced as Aktobe new manager. <a href="Ihor%20Rakhayev">Ihor Rakhayev</a> replaced Utkulbayev prior to the start of the <a href="2017%20Kazakhstan%20Premier%20League">2017</a> season.
